title: 107_hr1617
content: Title V of the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 is amended to promote equity and empowerment by adding a new part titled "PART D--EMPOWERING FUTURE ENTREPRENEURS." This includes a section with a short title and findings. The "Future Entrepreneurs of America Act" aims to empower young people to acquire skills and knowledge for success in the workforce. Research shows high interest in entrepreneurship among students, prompting states to prioritize entrepreneurship education as a viable career option. Entrepreneurship education for young people aims to increase motivation, develop individual opportunity, enhance personal growth, promote innovation, improve problem-solving and leadership skills, teach financial management, and foster optimistic and self-reliant attitudes for lifelong benefits. The importance of economic literacy, social security system, and personal savings is emphasized. The need to nurture the entrepreneurial spirit in students from grades 7 through 12 is highlighted. "State grant program under SEC. 5402 is established." In fiscal years with appropriations over $50,000,000, the Secretary will grant funds to States for entrepreneurship education programs for grades 7-12. Grants will be awarded to State educational agencies, contingent on an approved State plan outlining program usage. The Secretary will allocate funds to States based on student populations in grades 7 through 12. States must involve the business community, coordinate with other programs, and provide a description of program evaluation. The Secretary will allocate funds to States based on student populations in grades 7 through 12. States must involve the business community, coordinate with other programs, and provide a description of program evaluation. Appropriations ensure that States with approved plans receive a minimum of $400,000 annually. Reallocation of funds occurs for States without approved plans, directing funds to remaining States. Grant funds must be used to support entrepreneurship education programs for students at local educational agencies and public schools. The program aims to support entrepreneurship education for students in grades 7 through 12, focusing on lifelong learning and fostering an entrepreneurial spirit. Grants can be used for professional development for teachers and administrators. States receiving grants are limited to using 4% for administrative costs and must report to the Secretary. The program supports entrepreneurship education for students in grades 7-12, emphasizing lifelong learning and an entrepreneurial spirit. States receiving grants must report on programs supported and their evaluation results to the Secretary. In fiscal years with appropriations under $50,000,000, the Secretary can grant funds directly to local educational agencies and public schools for entrepreneurship education in grades 7-12. The Secretary will grant funds to establish a national Clearinghouse for entrepreneurship education programs. Organizations must apply competitively for a 5-year term to operate the Clearinghouse and use funds for instructional materials and best practices. The Secretary will grant funds to establish a national Clearinghouse for entrepreneurship education programs. The Clearinghouse will maintain a repository of instructional materials and information, disseminate materials to States and the public, and provide technical assistance for entrepreneurship education programs in secondary schools. The Clearinghouse for entrepreneurship education programs will consult with the Small Business Administration and ensure compliance with copyright laws. Federal agencies must submit information and materials on entrepreneurship education programs to the Clearinghouse. The Secretary will develop performance measures to evaluate programs assisted under sections 5402 and 5403, judging their effectiveness and identifying best practices for entrepreneurship education programs. The evaluation will also determine which programs can be replicated for technical assistance to States, localities, and the general public. The Secretary will transmit a report to Congress each fiscal year detailing the implementation status of the program, including evaluation results and descriptions of supported programs. In this part, entrepreneurship education refers to activities supervised by qualified teachers that help students explore business opportunities, acquire necessary skills, and develop entrepreneurial competencies. A qualified teacher is defined as someone with a valid teaching certification or recognized by the State educational agency. Authorization of appropriations is also discussed. For the purposes of entrepreneurship education, $60,000,000 is authorized annually from 2002 to 2006. The Secretary can allocate 2-5% for a clearinghouse and up to $200,000 for evaluation. Administrative costs are limited, with the majority of funds designated for grants. The Secretary will use appropriated funds for grants under section 5402 or 5403, excluding amounts designated for other purposes.
